repnme.cdata!:
Botswana - National HIV and AIDS Prevention
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Human
            Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Acquired Immunodeficiency
            Syndrome (AIDS) Prevention Support Project for Botswana were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. The lessons learned in this project
            were as follows: (i) the importance of intensive supervision
            in a country with limited prior World Bank Group (WBG)
            operational engagement and where there is no local staff
            must be underscored; (ii) innovative financing approaches
            require close coordination with the Client and cofinanciers,
            they can involve a trade-off, and require focus on results;
            (iii) operations of this scale and with a number of
            innovative interventions should incorporate a robust
            evaluation agenda to better inform design, course
            correction, and scale-up decisions in a timely and
            operationally relevant manner; (iv) slow progress in
            behavioral prevention questions the efficacy and targeting
            of Behavioral Change Communication (BCC) intervention, and
            it may be an unexpected adverse side effect of Botswana’s
            exemplary success in treatment; (v) in order to prioritize
            and concentrate allocations on cost-effective interventions
            for HIV prevention, it is critical to collect data. Data
            scarcity or inadequate use of data undermines strategic
            change and innovation; and (vi) through the integration
            pilots, Botswana National HIV and AIDS Prevention Support
            (BNAPS) illustrates that there is added value in
            capitalizing on the shared challenges, drivers, and
            potential solutions across the different disease categories,
            with broader health-systems strengthening measures and outcomes.
